Award.AwardTitle: AGEP: Colorado Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Colorado at Boulder will establish an enlarged Colorado Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate. This new Alliance will include original partner Colorado State University (CSU), and 2 new partners: the University Corporation of Atmospheric Research (UCAR), and the University of Colorado's urban Denver campus. The Alliance activities will be expanded to include an elite post-doctoral program that supports mentoring by the highest tier of award winning faculty, and a comprehensive professional evaluation to identify sustainable institutional factors that have the highest impact on promoting parity in graduate education and successful advancement to the professorate.

Problem Statement and Motivation. To remain globally competitive in science and technology, US institutions must increase the participation of groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, particularly at the doctoral level. In the coming decades underrepresented minorities will compose a growing fraction of the population, and if their representation within STEM fields does not increase, the total number of US STEM PhDs will decline substantially relative to the overall U.S. population. The Colorado AGEP has developed the following goals to address these national concerns:

. To translate the significant increases in minority STEM PhD enrollment realized during the last project period, into corresponding increases in PhD conferrals, such that the number of PhDs awarded increases from an average of 12 per year to an average of 24 per year over the next 5 years
. To increase minority STEM PhD enrollment by 67%, from the current 111 students to 185 students
. To develop stable cohorts of minority STEM doctoral students with retention rates comparable to their majority counterparts, and scholars that continue into the professoriate with tenure rates comparable to their majority counterparts
. To provide targeted professional development opportunities, which increase the competitiveness of recent PhD recipients and postdoctoral fellows for careers in academe
. To institutionalize a value added promotion and tenure credit for faculty that successfully mentor underrepresented minority graduate students through a PhD or postdoctoral fellowship
. To change institutional cultures and establish sustainable diversity programs that do not solely depend upon dedicated federal grant support by 2015

At Colorado Alliance universities, the value-added components to AGEP already in place are:

. Proactive faculty support system that recruits and retains underrepresented PhD students and postdoctoral fellows;
. Strong commitment to AGEP's goals at the highest administrative levels at each institution; and
. Significant financial support from Alliance institutions. Together, the Colorado Alliance institutions have committed $1 million per year to support AGEP activities.

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in its comprehensive faculty-driven effort to seamlessly transfer students through doctoral education and career placement. The net gain will be 10 new, highly competitively trained postdoctoral fellows that will enter the professorate, and 120 new underrepresented PhD graduates.

The broader impacts of this proposal lie in its potential to serve as a national model for the integration of a broad array of previously independent diversity programs, which will catalyze the institutionalization of AGEP's efforts, and significantly contribute to the diversity of the professoriate for generations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the NSF Colorado Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate was to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students enrolled in and graduating from doctoral programs in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields at the University of Colorado Boulder and Colorado State University. Since the start of the award in 2007, the two Colorado institutions conferred 149 STEM doctoral degrees on URM students, an average of 17 per year compared to an average of 7 per year Pre-AGEP.

 

In addition to successfully reaching the numerical goals of AGEP, a lasting impact of the award was institutional change at both Colorado institutions. A key strategy employed by both campuses was to gain the support of STEM faculty by increasing their awareness of and commitment to diversity, and directly involving them as change agents. Both institutions developed recruiting methods that included faculty visits to universities with high percentages of STEM URM undergraduates, faculty and graduate student presence at national conferences such as SACNAS and ABRCMS, the establishment of systems to effectively communicate with students whose names have been gathered at conferences, and providing travel expenses for prospective URM doctoral students to visit campuses. The pre-AGEP centralized graduate student recruiting efforts transformed into department-centric recruiting efforts involving numerous faculty and current URM doctoral students. The result of these efforts is that Colorado institutions are recruiting both more URM students and URM students who are more likely to succeed academically.

 

The AGEP award increased funding for direct doctoral student support. As a result, faculty became incentivized to reach out to URM students and personally recruit them. Because the funding allocated to departments for URM graduate student support was tied to the students’ academic success, departmental leadership and faculty discovered new strategies to improve retention and degree completion. These collective efforts have led to positive changes that continue to impact all doctoral students in STEM departments. Through their increasing awareness of how to best recruit and mentor URM students, faculty have improved overall recruiting and mentoring activities for all students.

 

The AGEP award facilitated and incentivized CU-Boulder and CSU to provide professional development training opportunities to URM STEM doctoral students by funding travel for students presenting their research at national conferences in their disciplines, and developing a wide range of skill building and career development workshops. The focus on both campuses was to create a supportive and welcoming academic environment by providing socialization, professional development, and mentoring opportunities for underrepresented doctoral students, and these efforts have been institutionalized.

 

Postdoctoral training was a component of the Colorado AGEP, and the universities supported the development of seven URM PhD recipients. In 2014, CU-Boulder joined the collaboration with the Universities of California and Michigan to extend the Chancellor’s Postdoctoral Fellowships Program to CU-Boulder. This University funded program offers fellowships in all academic fields, and provides faculty mentoring and professional development opportunities.
